content.description: If you don't look, your cuticles are both totally fine and profusely bleeding at the same time. A short traverse from climbers right --> left, but also a useful training circuit. Move through good crimps with okay feet, keeping your body low and moving until terrain turns less than vertical. If you want to train hard you can always hop into the high crack from the end and traverse back right, complete the loop and continue looping until you can't feel your forearms. If you've ever wanted to send V∞ this is your chance.
content.protection: A couple pads will cover the traverse, but it's probably overkill as you're no more than 3 feet off the ground for the most of this.
content.location: Left of boulder proper, on vertical/less than vertical terrain. Start on climbers right (right before overhanging section, traverse left (then up, then right, then down, and repeat?)

content.description: Sit start left of the roof on a big sloping hold, traverse right through juggy horizontals then climb through a large square flake into the mantle (crux).
A short but fun problem on the east end boulder. Start under the small roof on the far right of the boulder, move up and mantle on a slopey heel, using the top arete. Top out.
content.protection: A single pad should be sufficient.
content.location: Furthest route on climber's right. Start on two good crimps under the small roof.

content.description: Not TECHNICALLY a freestanding boulder, but a short section of the wrap-around cliff. This place provides a short and steep place for some FUN overhanging climbing on Mamacoke. Shady for the vast majority of the day. This place has some of the best problems around. So far routes have been climbed up to V3/V4, but there is defiantly a few harder routes to be put up. The landings are very good and not too high so one or two pads is almost always enough.
